We are going on a ride through the world of stability. At the highest level, a stablecoin is a crypto asset with relatively stable purchasing power. That is the key idea.

Purchasing power does not swing wildly from day to day. You will often hear that stablecoins are pegged to a currency, a commodity, or a financial instrument. That description is a decent starting point, but it is not the full story.
Here is a simple example. If you bought apples with Bitcoin six months ago, you would get a very different amount than today. That is changing purchasing power.
It makes Bitcoin a poor unit for everyday pricing. If you bought apples with dollars, you would likely get a similar amount over time. That is what we mean by stable purchasing power.
Assets with wild price swings are bad examples of stable purchasing power. Stablecoins aim to keep purchasing power relatively steady. If that is the only thing you remember, you are already ahead.
Now, why do we care about stablecoins? Because money matters. Not in a greedy way, but in the practical way that everyday life depends on it.

In society, we need low volatility money to do three things well. In web3, we need a crypto version of the same thing. The three functions of money are store of value, unit of account, and medium of exchange.
Store of value means you can keep wealth over time. A bank account, stocks, and crypto are all examples. Apples are a bad store of value because they rot.
Unit of account means we price things in a consistent way. We price groceries in dollars. Pricing in Bitcoin would be chaotic because it fluctuates so much.
Medium of exchange means we use money to trade with each other. Buying groceries with dollars is easy. Buying groceries with car tires is not.

For everyday life to work, money needs to serve all three roles. In web3, we need a decentralized money that can do the same. We need to price things without wild swings, store wealth safely, and trade smoothly.

Ethereum is a strong store of value and a great medium of exchange. But it is not a great unit of account yet, because its purchasing power still moves around too much. Maybe in the future, as Ethereum adoption grows, it becomes stable enough on its own.
If that happens, we might not need stablecoins. But today, it is still too volatile for everyday pricing. I still call Ethereum ultrasound money because I think it is a fantastic store of value.
